poem:
### The Sneakers of Christmas Past  

In the glow of morning, clarity arrives –  
Santa's guise betrayed by familiar soles.  
A child's eye, keen, puzzles over schemes,  
Uncle Dan's sneakers in the snow.  
The chimera of belief, unraveling  
In quiet revelations.  
Oh, the joy of discovery  
And the sweet, stubborn innocence  
Of knowing too much, too soon.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Christmas that went wrong: Why on earth was Santa wearing my uncle’s sneakers? As a child, I was an amateur detective; a master of argument and the suspicious side-eye. The adult world seemed to be defined by determined, capable people making important decisions and I was desperate to be one of them. In short, I was precocious. And I’m sorry to everybody I came up against. Especially my uncle Dan. Christmas 1989 was exciting for four-year-old". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
